Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Comparative statistical phylogeography of Japanese birds

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major goal of modern science is to explain biological diversity: where it is, where it comes from, and how it evolves. New molecular approaches using DNA samples allow us to peer into the evolutionary past like never before to answer some long-standing questions about the evolution of life. For example, some DNA sequences are thought to change at a relatively constant rate, so, by comparing the number of DNA differences between two species, we can get a general idea about when they last shared a common ancestor. If we do this for many species, we can determine the timeframe of diversification in a group of organisms in a specific area.

For my research, I am looking at the timeframe of evolution in East Asian birds. There is a debate over whether birds speciated during the glacial cycles that were associated with the Pleistocene epoch (< 1.8 million years ago) or whether they speciated before the glacial cycles during the Pliocene epoch (> 1.8 million years ago). To help answer this question, I spent the summer of 2010 in Japan on an NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute fellowship to collect bird DNA samples. My host and local Japanese collaborator was Dr. Isao Nishiumi, curator of birds at the Japanese National Museum of Nature and Science. Dr. Nishiumi was the ideal host for me because natural history museums have the resources to collect and curate bird DNA specimens. Dr. Nishiumi already had many samples available, and I worked during the summer to fill in some of the gaps in our sampling.

My summer research was a big success, and I eventually returned to the United States will over 800 bird DNA samples to begin my molecular analyses. I expect to finish the molecular work this summer. Dr. Nishiumi and I have already finished one project together, which was recently submitted for publication. In this paper, we found evidence for Pleistocene speciation. We will need to examine many more species to see if a general pattern emerges. We expect several more publications over the next year. My career goal is to continue to study avian evolution in East Asia. Thus, I hope to continue my collaboration with Dr. Nishiumi, which I think has been very beneficial to both of us.
